abstract.p: George E Herman letter on Aug 29 article warns genetic factors may be important cause of malignant melanoma

block.p: I believe the column ''Yet Another Reminder: Forget the Suntan'' put a bit too much emphasis on sunlight as a major causal factor for melanoma.
I believe the column ''Yet Another Reminder: Forget the Suntan'' put a bit too much emphasis on sunlight as a major causal factor for melanoma.

I have had three primary melanomas removed over the past 27 years and not one of them was in an area generally available to sunlight. By contrast in 40 some years as a CBS News correspondent I stood for untold hours outside government buildings in the sun and have had about 20 basal cell carcinomas removed from my sun-tanned face, but no melanomas.

Consequently I avoid the sun in general; I'm tired of doctors coming at my face with knives. President Lyndon Johnson had numerous carcinomas removed from the backs of his sun-tanned hands but no melanomas. A cousin of mine died from an untreated melanoma on his lower back, well below his sun-tanned belt line.

Two dermatologists tell me the role of sunlight in causing melanoma is currently uncertain, and a possibly important role is suspected for genetic susceptibility. Once again it is important to keep apprised of your extended family's health history.
